slides.title: Introduction to Averages
slides.content:
Average is one of the most practical and frequently tested topics in SSC GD, appearing in 2-3 questions per exam.

What is Average?
Average (or Arithmetic Mean) is the central value of a set of numbers. It represents the sum of all values divided by the count of values.

Formula:
Average = Sum of all observations / Number of observations

Or: Average = Total / Count

Example 1: Find average of 10, 20, 30
Sum = 10 + 20 + 30 = 60
Count = 3
Average = 60/3 = 20

Example 2: Find average of 5, 8, 12, 15, 20
Sum = 5 + 8 + 12 + 15 + 20 = 60
Count = 5
Average = 60/5 = 12

Why Averages is Important:
- Common in daily life (marks, temperature, speed, etc.)
- 2-3 questions in SSC GD exam
- Easy scoring topic with formulas
- Foundation for statistics
- Practical applications everywhere

Key Points:
- Average is always between the smallest and largest value
- If all numbers are same, average equals that number
- Average can be a decimal/fraction even if all numbers are integers

Example 3: Average of 10, 10, 10
Average = (10+10+10)/3 = 30/3 = 10
(When all equal, average equals that value)

Example 4: Average of 5, 10, 12
Smallest = 5, Largest = 12
Average = (5+10+12)/3 = 27/3 = 9
Note: 5 < 9 < 12 ‚úì

Basic Properties:

1. Sum from Average:
If average of n numbers is A, then:
Sum = Average √ó Count = A √ó n

Example: Average of 5 numbers is 20
Sum = 20 √ó 5 = 100

2. Finding Missing Number:
If average of n numbers is known and (n-1) numbers are given:
Missing number = (Average √ó n) - Sum of given numbers

Example: Average of 4 numbers is 25. Three numbers are 20, 22, 28. Find fourth.
Sum of 4 numbers = 25 √ó 4 = 100
Sum of 3 numbers = 20 + 22 + 28 = 70
Fourth number = 100 - 70 = 30

3. Effect of Adding/Removing:
When a number is added/removed, average changes unless:
- The added/removed number equals the current average

Example: Average of 5 numbers is 20 (sum = 100)
If we add 20: New sum = 120, New count = 6
New average = 120/6 = 20 (unchanged)

If we add 30: New sum = 130, New count = 6
New average = 130/6 = 21.67 (increased)

Average of First n Natural Numbers:

Formula: Average = (n+1)/2

Example: Average of first 10 natural numbers
Numbers: 1, 2, 3, ..., 10
Average = (10+1)/2 = 11/2 = 5.5

Verification: Sum = 1+2+...+10 = 55
Average = 55/10 = 5.5 ‚úì

Average of First n Even Numbers:

Formula: Average = n+1

Example: Average of first 5 even numbers
Numbers: 2, 4, 6, 8, 10
Average = 5+1 = 6

Verification: Sum = 30, Count = 5
Average = 30/5 = 6 ‚úì

Average of First n Odd Numbers:

Formula: Average = n

Example: Average of first 5 odd numbers
Numbers: 1, 3, 5, 7, 9
Average = 5

Verification: Sum = 25, Count = 5
Average = 25/5 = 5 ‚úì

Average of Consecutive Numbers:

For any consecutive numbers:
Average = (First + Last)/2

Example 1: Average of 5, 6, 7, 8, 9
Average = (5+9)/2 = 14/2 = 7

Example 2: Average of 15, 16, 17, 18, 19, 20
Average = (15+20)/2 = 35/2 = 17.5

This also works for:
- Consecutive even numbers
- Consecutive odd numbers
- Any arithmetic progression

Types of Problems:

1. Direct Calculation: Find average given numbers
2. Finding Sum: Given average and count
3. Finding Count: Given average and sum
4. Finding Missing: Given average and some numbers
5. Change in Average: When numbers added/removed
6. Combined Average: Average of multiple groups
7. Age Average: Average age problems
8. Speed Average: Average speed problems

Common Mistakes:
- Forgetting to divide by count
- Adding averages (can't add averages directly)
- Wrong count of numbers
- Calculation errors

Exam Strategy:
- Identify problem type quickly
- Use appropriate formula
- Calculate systematically
- Verify answer makes sense
- Check if answer is in range (min to max)

slides.title: Finding Average and Sum
slides.content:
Understanding the relationship between average, sum, and count is fundamental to solving all average problems.

Core Formula Triangle:

        SUM
       /   \
      /     \
  AVERAGE √ó COUNT

From this triangle:
1. Average = Sum / Count
2. Sum = Average √ó Count
3. Count = Sum / Average

Type 1: Direct Average Calculation

Given: Numbers
Find: Average
Method: Sum all numbers and divide by count

Example 1: Find average of 12, 15, 18, 21, 24
Sum = 12 + 15 + 18 + 21 + 24 = 90
Count = 5
Average = 90/5 = 18

Example 2: Find average of 7, 14, 21, 28, 35, 42
Sum = 7 + 14 + 21 + 28 + 35 + 42 = 147
Count = 6
Average = 147/6 = 24.5

Shortcut for Arithmetic Progression:
If numbers are in AP (constant difference):
Average = (First + Last)/2

For Example 1: Average = (12+24)/2 = 18 ‚úì
For Example 2: Average = (7+42)/2 = 24.5 ‚úì

Type 2: Finding Sum from Average

Given: Average and Count
Find: Sum
Formula: Sum = Average √ó Count

Example 1: Average of 8 numbers is 35. Find their sum.
Sum = 35 √ó 8 = 280

Example 2: Average marks of 40 students is 62. Find total marks.
Total = 62 √ó 40 = 2480

Example 3: Average age of 5 people is 28 years. After 3 years, what will be their total age?
Current total = 28 √ó 5 = 140 years
After 3 years, each increases by 3 years
Increase in total = 3 √ó 5 = 15 years
New total = 140 + 15 = 155 years

Alternatively:
New average = 28 + 3 = 31 years
New total = 31 √ó 5 = 155 years ‚úì

Type 3: Finding Count from Average and Sum

Given: Average and Sum
Find: Count
Formula: Count = Sum / Average

Example 1: Sum is 360 and average is 40. How many numbers?
Count = 360/40 = 9 numbers

Example 2: Total runs scored is 3600 and average is 45. How many innings?
Innings = 3600/45 = 80

Type 4: Finding One Number When Average is Given

Example 1: Average of 5 numbers is 30. Four numbers are 25, 28, 32, 35. Find the fifth.
Total sum = 30 √ó 5 = 150
Sum of 4 numbers = 25 + 28 + 32 + 35 = 120
Fifth number = 150 - 120 = 30

Example 2: Average of 6 numbers is 45. If one number 48 is excluded, what is new average?
Original sum = 45 √ó 6 = 270
New sum = 270 - 48 = 222
New count = 5
New average = 222/5 = 44.4

Example 3: Average of 7 numbers is 50. If one number is increased by 14, what is new average?
Original sum = 50 √ó 7 = 350
New sum = 350 + 14 = 364
Count remains = 7
New average = 364/7 = 52

Alternatively:
Increase per number = 14/7 = 2
New average = 50 + 2 = 52 ‚úì

Type 5: Effect of Wrong Entry

Example 1: Average of 10 numbers is 50. One number 40 was wrongly taken as 60. Find correct average.

Wrong sum = 50 √ó 10 = 500
Correction needed = 60 - 40 = 20 (excess)
Correct sum = 500 - 20 = 480
Correct average = 480/10 = 48

Example 2: Average of 20 observations is 35. Later found two observations 42 and 38 were wrongly read as 24 and 35. Find correct average.

Wrong sum = 35 √ó 20 = 700
First correction: 42 - 24 = +18
Second correction: 38 - 35 = +3
Total correction = +21
Correct sum = 700 + 21 = 721
Correct average = 721/20 = 36.05

Type 6: Balancing Method

Useful when numbers are close to a value.

Example: Find average of 47, 52, 48, 53, 45

Choose reference point: 50
Deviations: -3, +2, -2, +3, -5
Sum of deviations = -3+2-2+3-5 = -5
Average deviation = -5/5 = -1
Actual average = 50 + (-1) = 49

Verification:
Sum = 47+52+48+53+45 = 245
Average = 245/5 = 49 ‚úì

Type 7: Weighted Average (Introduction)

When different items have different importance/weight:

Example: A student scores 80 in a 3-credit subject and 90 in a 2-credit subject. Find weighted average.

Weighted sum = (80 √ó 3) + (90 √ó 2) = 240 + 180 = 420
Total credits = 3 + 2 = 5
Weighted average = 420/5 = 84

(Simple average would be (80+90)/2 = 85, but weighted is 84 because 80 has more weight)

Applications:

1. Academic: Average marks calculation
2. Sports: Average runs, goals, points
3. Finance: Average income, expenditure
4. Age: Average age of family, class
5. Speed: Average speed of journey
6. Temperature: Average temperature
7. Daily life: Average consumption, production

Quick Calculations:

1. If sum is obvious:
Use sum directly

2. If numbers in AP:
Use (First + Last)/2

3. If numbers close:
Use balancing method

4. If specific formulas apply:
First n natural, even, odd numbers

Exam Tips:
- Always write: Average = Sum/Count
- Calculate sum carefully
- Verify answer is in range
- Use shortcuts where applicable
- Check if answer is reasonable

question.questionText: The average of 6 numbers is 30. If one number 42 is excluded, what is the new average?
question.explanation: Original sum = 30 √ó 6 = 180. After excluding 42: New sum = 180 - 42 = 138. New count = 5. New average = 138/5 = 27.6 ‚âà 28. Answer: 28.

slides.title: Combined Average and Groups
slides.content:
Combined average problems involve finding the average of multiple groups combined together.

Combined Average Formula:

When two groups are combined:
Combined Average = (n‚ÇÅA‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇA‚ÇÇ)/(n‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇ)

Where:
n‚ÇÅ = count in first group
A‚ÇÅ = average of first group
n‚ÇÇ = count in second group
A‚ÇÇ = average of second group

Example 1: Average age of 20 boys is 12 years and average age of 30 girls is 10 years. Find combined average.

Solution:
n‚ÇÅ = 20, A‚ÇÅ = 12
n‚ÇÇ = 30, A‚ÇÇ = 10

Combined average = (20√ó12 + 30√ó10)/(20+30)
                  = (240 + 300)/50
                  = 540/50
                  = 10.8 years

Example 2: Average marks of 25 students in Section A is 60 and of 35 students in Section B is 70. Find average marks of all students.

Solution:
Total marks in A = 25 √ó 60 = 1500
Total marks in B = 35 √ó 70 = 2450
Total marks = 1500 + 2450 = 3950
Total students = 25 + 35 = 60
Average = 3950/60 = 65.83 marks

Three Groups:

Combined Average = (n‚ÇÅA‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇA‚ÇÇ + n‚ÇÉA‚ÇÉ)/(n‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇ + n‚ÇÉ)

Example: Average of 10 numbers is 20, of 15 numbers is 25, and of 20 numbers is 30. Find combined average.

Solution:
Sum‚ÇÅ = 10 √ó 20 = 200
Sum‚ÇÇ = 15 √ó 25 = 375
Sum‚ÇÉ = 20 √ó 30 = 600

Total sum = 200 + 375 + 600 = 1175
Total count = 10 + 15 + 20 = 45

Combined average = 1175/45 = 26.11

Finding Group Average:

Example 1: Combined average of 50 students is 40. If average of 30 students is 35, find average of remaining 20.

Solution:
Total marks of 50 = 50 √ó 40 = 2000
Marks of 30 = 30 √ó 35 = 1050
Marks of 20 = 2000 - 1050 = 950
Average of 20 = 950/20 = 47.5

Example 2: Average of 40 results is 30. Average of first 10 is 25 and of last 10 is 30. Find average of middle 20.

Solution:
Total sum = 40 √ó 30 = 1200
Sum of first 10 = 10 √ó 25 = 250
Sum of last 10 = 10 √ó 30 = 300
Sum of middle 20 = 1200 - 250 - 300 = 650
Average of middle 20 = 650/20 = 32.5

Replacement Problems:

Example 1: Average of 10 numbers is 50. If one number 60 is replaced by 80, what is new average?

Solution:
Original sum = 10 √ó 50 = 500
Change = 80 - 60 = +20
New sum = 500 + 20 = 520
New average = 520/10 = 52

Alternatively:
Increase per number = 20/10 = 2
New average = 50 + 2 = 52

Example 2: Average weight of 20 students is 50 kg. If a student of 45 kg leaves and a new student joins, the average becomes 50.5 kg. Find weight of new student.

Solution:
Original total = 20 √ó 50 = 1000 kg
New total = 20 √ó 50.5 = 1010 kg
Increase = 1010 - 1000 = 10 kg

New student weight = 45 + 10 = 55 kg

Verification:
(1000 - 45 + 55)/20 = 1010/20 = 50.5 ‚úì

Joining and Leaving:

Example 1: Average age of 8 people is 30 years. A person aged 40 leaves and two persons aged 25 and 35 join. Find new average.

Solution:
Original total = 8 √ó 30 = 240 years
After leaving: 240 - 40 = 200 years (7 people)
After joining: 200 + 25 + 35 = 260 years (9 people)
New average = 260/9 = 28.89 years

Example 2: Average of 6 numbers is 35. If 2 numbers with average 40 are removed and 3 numbers with average 30 are added, find new average.

Solution:
Original sum = 6 √ó 35 = 210
Removed sum = 2 √ó 40 = 80
Added sum = 3 √ó 30 = 90

New sum = 210 - 80 + 90 = 220
New count = 6 - 2 + 3 = 7
New average = 220/7 = 31.43

Sequential Changes:

Example: Average of 5 numbers is 20. When one number is added, average becomes 22. When another number is added, average becomes 24. Find the two added numbers.

Solution:
Initial sum = 5 √ó 20 = 100

After first addition:
New sum = 6 √ó 22 = 132
First added number = 132 - 100 = 32

After second addition:
New sum = 7 √ó 24 = 168
Second added number = 168 - 132 = 36

Distribution with Same Total:

Example: 100 students have average marks 50. They are divided into two groups of 60 and 40. If average of first group is 55, find average of second.

Solution:
Total marks = 100 √ó 50 = 5000
Marks of first 60 = 60 √ó 55 = 3300
Marks of second 40 = 5000 - 3300 = 1700
Average of second 40 = 1700/40 = 42.5

Equal Groups:

Example: Average of 60 students is 40. They are divided into 3 equal groups. If first group has average 35 and second has 40, find third group's average.

Solution:
Each group has 60/3 = 20 students
Total = 60 √ó 40 = 2400

Group 1 sum = 20 √ó 35 = 700
Group 2 sum = 20 √ó 40 = 800
Group 3 sum = 2400 - 700 - 800 = 900

Group 3 average = 900/20 = 45

Weighted Average Application:

Example: In a class of 50, boys average 70 and girls average 80. If class average is 72, how many boys and girls?

Solution:
Let boys = x, then girls = 50-x

Total marks = (x √ó 70) + ((50-x) √ó 80)
            = 70x + 4000 - 80x
            = 4000 - 10x

Also, total marks = 50 √ó 72 = 3600

Therefore: 4000 - 10x = 3600
10x = 400
x = 40

Boys = 40, Girls = 10

Exam Tips:
- For combined groups, find total sum first
- Track count changes carefully
- For replacement, find the difference
- Use algebra for unknown counts
- Verify final answer makes sense

slides.title: Average Speed and Distance
slides.content:
Average speed problems are special cases where distance and time are involved.

Average Speed:

Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time

Important: Average speed ‚â† Average of speeds

Example 1: A person travels 100 km in 2 hours and then 150 km in 3 hours. Find average speed.

Solution:
Total distance = 100 + 150 = 250 km
Total time = 2 + 3 = 5 hours
Average speed = 250/5 = 50 km/h

Note: Average of speeds = (50 + 50)/2 = 50 km/h (coincidentally same)
But this is not the correct method!

Example 2: A car travels first half distance at 40 km/h and second half at 60 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution Method 1 (Correct):
Let total distance = 120 km (LCM of 40 and 60)
First half = 60 km at 40 km/h, time = 60/40 = 1.5 hours
Second half = 60 km at 60 km/h, time = 60/60 = 1 hour

Total distance = 120 km
Total time = 1.5 + 1 = 2.5 hours
Average speed = 120/2.5 = 48 km/h

Solution Method 2 (Formula):
When equal distances covered at speeds v‚ÇÅ and v‚ÇÇ:
Average speed = (2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ)/(v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)

Average speed = (2 √ó 40 √ó 60)/(40 + 60)
               = 4800/100
               = 48 km/h

Equal Distance Formula:

For two equal distances at speeds v‚ÇÅ and v‚ÇÇ:
Average Speed = (2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ)/(v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)

This is the Harmonic Mean of two speeds.

Example 1: A person goes from A to B at 30 km/h and returns at 20 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Average speed = (2 √ó 30 √ó 20)/(30 + 20)
               = 1200/50
               = 24 km/h

(NOT (30+20)/2 = 25 km/h!)

Example 2: Train travels first 100 km at 50 km/h and next 100 km at 60 km/h. Average speed?

Solution:
Average = (2 √ó 50 √ó 60)/(50 + 60)
        = 6000/110
        = 54.55 km/h

Three Equal Parts:

If three equal distances at speeds v‚ÇÅ, v‚ÇÇ, v‚ÇÉ:
Average Speed = (3v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇv‚ÇÉ)/(v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ + v‚ÇÇv‚ÇÉ + v‚ÇÉv‚ÇÅ)

Example: A travels equal distances at 20, 30, and 60 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Average = (3 √ó 20 √ó 30 √ó 60)/[(20√ó30) + (30√ó60) + (60√ó20)]
        = 108000/[600 + 1800 + 1200]
        = 108000/3600
        = 30 km/h

Equal Time Formula:

When equal time spent at different speeds:
Average Speed = (v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)/2 (Arithmetic Mean)

Example 1: A person drives at 40 km/h for 2 hours and at 60 km/h for 2 hours. Average speed?

Solution Method 1:
Distance‚ÇÅ = 40 √ó 2 = 80 km
Distance‚ÇÇ = 60 √ó 2 = 120 km
Total distance = 200 km
Total time = 4 hours
Average = 200/4 = 50 km/h

Solution Method 2 (Formula):
Average = (40 + 60)/2 = 50 km/h

Example 2: A car travels at 30 km/h, 40 km/h, and 50 km/h for equal durations. Average speed?

Solution:
Average = (30 + 40 + 50)/3 = 120/3 = 40 km/h

Mixed Problems:

Example 1: A person travels 120 km at 60 km/h and 180 km at 90 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Time‚ÇÅ = 120/60 = 2 hours
Time‚ÇÇ = 180/90 = 2 hours
Total distance = 120 + 180 = 300 km
Total time = 2 + 2 = 4 hours
Average speed = 300/4 = 75 km/h

Example 2: A train covers first one-third distance at 20 km/h, second one-third at 30 km/h, and last one-third at 60 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Let total distance = 60 km (LCM)
Each part = 20 km

Time‚ÇÅ = 20/20 = 1 hour
Time‚ÇÇ = 20/30 = 2/3 hour
Time‚ÇÉ = 20/60 = 1/3 hour

Total time = 1 + 2/3 + 1/3 = 2 hours
Average speed = 60/2 = 30 km/h

Rest Period Inclusion:

Example: A person walks 40 km at 10 km/h, then rests for 2 hours, then walks another 20 km at 10 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Time for first 40 km = 40/10 = 4 hours
Rest time = 2 hours
Time for next 20 km = 20/10 = 2 hours

Total distance = 40 + 20 = 60 km
Total time = 4 + 2 + 2 = 8 hours
Average speed = 60/8 = 7.5 km/h

Note: Rest time is included in total time!

Partial Journey:

Example: A travels half time at 40 km/h and half time at 60 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Since equal time:
Average = (40 + 60)/2 = 50 km/h

Example: A travels half distance at 30 km/h. If average speed for whole journey is 45 km/h, find speed for second half.

Solution:
Let second half speed = v
Using equal distance formula:
45 = (2 √ó 30 √ó v)/(30 + v)
45(30 + v) = 60v
1350 + 45v = 60v
1350 = 15v
v = 90 km/h

Round Trip:

Example: A goes from home to office at 30 km/h and returns at 45 km/h. Find average speed for entire journey.

Solution:
This is equal distance problem:
Average = (2 √ó 30 √ó 45)/(30 + 45)
        = 2700/75
        = 36 km/h

Different Modes:

Example: A person travels 60 km by car at 60 km/h, then 40 km by train at 80 km/h. Find average speed.

Solution:
Time by car = 60/60 = 1 hour
Time by train = 40/80 = 0.5 hour
Total distance = 100 km
Total time = 1.5 hours
Average speed = 100/1.5 = 66.67 km/h

Key Formulas Summary:

1. General: Average Speed = Total Distance / Total Time
2. Equal Distance (2 speeds): (2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ)/(v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)
3. Equal Time (2 speeds): (v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)/2
4. Equal Distance (3 speeds): (3v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇv‚ÇÉ)/(v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ + v‚ÇÇv‚ÇÉ + v‚ÇÉv‚ÇÅ)

Common Mistakes:
- Taking average of speeds directly
- Forgetting rest time
- Confusing equal distance vs equal time
- Using wrong formula

Exam Tips:
- Identify: Equal distance or equal time?
- Use appropriate formula
- For general case, calculate time first
- Average speed < Arithmetic mean (for unequal distances)
- Always use Total Distance / Total Time when in doubt

question.questionText: A person travels from A to B at 40 km/h and returns from B to A at 60 km/h. What is the average speed for the entire journey?
question.explanation: For equal distances: Average speed = (2√óv‚ÇÅ√óv‚ÇÇ)/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ) = (2√ó40√ó60)/(40+60) = 4800/100 = 48 km/h. Answer: 48 km/h.

slides.title: Age Average Problems
slides.content:
Age average problems are very common in SSC GD and involve understanding how ages change over time.

Key Principle:
When time passes, everyone's age increases equally.
If n people age by t years each:
Total age increase = n √ó t

Example 1: Average age of 5 people is 30 years. After 5 years, what will be average age?

Solution:
Current total age = 5 √ó 30 = 150 years
After 5 years, each person's age increases by 5
Total increase = 5 √ó 5 = 25 years
New total = 150 + 25 = 175 years
New average = 175/5 = 35 years

Shortcut: New average = 30 + 5 = 35 years

Rule: When all members age by t years, average also increases by t years.

Example 2: Average age of 8 members was 28 years. 4 years ago, what was their average age?

Solution:
Current total = 8 √ó 28 = 224 years
4 years ago, each was 4 years younger
Total decrease = 8 √ó 4 = 32 years
Past total = 224 - 32 = 192 years
Past average = 192/8 = 24 years

Shortcut: Past average = 28 - 4 = 24 years

Member Joins:

Example 1: Average age of 6 family members is 25 years. A baby is born. After 2 years, what is average age?

Solution:
Current total = 6 √ó 25 = 150 years

After 2 years:
- 6 original members each age by 2: 150 + (6√ó2) = 162 years
- Baby's age = 2 years
- Total members = 7

Total age = 162 + 2 = 164 years
Average = 164/7 = 23.43 years

Example 2: Average age of 10 students is 20 years. When a new student joins, average becomes 19.5 years. Find age of new student.

Solution:
Original total = 10 √ó 20 = 200 years
New total = 11 √ó 19.5 = 214.5 years
New student age = 214.5 - 200 = 14.5 years

Member Leaves:

Example: Average age of 9 members is 30 years. When one member aged 45 leaves, what is new average?

Solution:
Original total = 9 √ó 30 = 270 years
After leaving = 270 - 45 = 225 years
New count = 8
New average = 225/8 = 28.125 years

Replacement:

Example 1: Average age of 11 players is 28 years. If a player aged 35 is replaced by another, average decreases by 1 year. Find age of new player.

Solution:
New average = 28 - 1 = 27 years
Original total = 11 √ó 28 = 308 years
New total = 11 √ó 27 = 297 years
Decrease = 308 - 297 = 11 years

Since one player replaced:
New player age = 35 - 11 = 24 years

Example 2: Average age of 15 members is 32 years. Two members aged 30 and 35 leave and two new members join. If average increases by 2 years, find total age of new members.

Solution:
New average = 32 + 2 = 34 years
Original total = 15 √ó 32 = 480 years
New total = 15 √ó 34 = 510 years
Increase needed = 510 - 480 = 30 years

Age removed = 30 + 35 = 65 years
Age added = 65 + 30 = 95 years

Total age of new members = 95 years

Teacher-Student Problems:

Example 1: Average age of 40 students is 15 years. When teacher's age is included, average becomes 16 years. Find teacher's age.

Solution:
Total age of students = 40 √ó 15 = 600 years
Total with teacher = 41 √ó 16 = 656 years
Teacher's age = 656 - 600 = 56 years

Example 2: Average age of 30 students and their teacher is 16 years. If teacher's age is excluded, average becomes 15 years. Find teacher's age.

Solution:
Total with teacher = 31 √ó 16 = 496 years
Total students = 30 √ó 15 = 450 years
Teacher's age = 496 - 450 = 46 years

Family Age Problems:

Example 1: Average age of husband, wife and child is 27 years. Average age of husband and wife is 30 years. Find child's age.

Solution:
Total of all three = 3 √ó 27 = 81 years
Total of husband and wife = 2 √ó 30 = 60 years
Child's age = 81 - 60 = 21 years

Example 2: Average age of father and son is 30 years. Average age of father, mother and son is 28 years. Find mother's age.

Solution:
Total of father and son = 2 √ó 30 = 60 years
Total of all three = 3 √ó 28 = 84 years
Mother's age = 84 - 60 = 24 years

Birth Impact:

Example: Average age of 4 family members is 25 years. A baby is born and after 5 years, average age of family is 20 years. Find present age of baby.

Solution:
Present total of 4 = 4 √ó 25 = 100 years
Let baby's present age = x years

After 5 years:
Total of 4 members = 100 + (4√ó5) = 120 years
Baby's age = x + 5 years
Total of 5 members = 120 + (x+5) = 125 + x

Given average = 20:
(125 + x)/5 = 20
125 + x = 100
x = -25 (not possible)

Let me reconsider: Baby born now, so current age = 0
After 5 years:
Four members: 100 + 20 = 120 years
Baby: 5 years
Total: 125 years, Count: 5
Average = 125/5 = 25 years (not 20)

The problem setup needs baby's birth to be in past.

Complex Age Problem:

Example: 8 years ago, average age of a family of 4 was 24 years. A child is born and after 2 years from now, the average age becomes 22 years. Find present age of child.

Solution:
8 years ago:
Total = 4 √ó 24 = 96 years

Present (8 years later):
Total of original 4 = 96 + (4√ó8) = 128 years

Let child's present age = x years

2 years from now:
Original 4 members: 128 + (4√ó2) = 136 years
Child: x + 2 years
Total: 136 + x + 2 = 138 + x
Count: 5

Given average = 22:
(138 + x)/5 = 22
138 + x = 110
x = -28 (not possible)

This indicates child was born after the reference point or problem has different setup.

Exam Tips:
- When all age by t, average increases by t
- For joining/leaving, find total change
- For replacement, compare before and after
- Draw timeline if problem is complex
- Verify answer is realistic (positive age)

slides.title: Special Average Problems
slides.content:
These are unique problem types that frequently appear in exams.

Consecutive Numbers Average:

For any consecutive numbers:
Average = (First + Last)/2
Also = Middle term (if odd count)

Example 1: Find average of 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17
Average = (11 + 17)/2 = 28/2 = 14
Also, middle term = 14 ‚úì

Example 2: Average of 5 consecutive numbers is 27. Find the numbers.
Middle number = 27
Numbers: 25, 26, 27, 28, 29

Example 3: Average of 6 consecutive even numbers is 15. Find the numbers.
Since even count, average lies between middle two
(14 + 16)/2 = 15
Numbers: 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, 20

Sum Formula Application:

Example 1: Average of first 50 natural numbers.
Sum = n(n+1)/2 = 50(51)/2 = 1275
Average = 1275/50 = 25.5

Or use direct formula: Average = (n+1)/2 = 51/2 = 25.5

Example 2: Average of first 20 even numbers.
Numbers: 2, 4, 6, ..., 40
Sum = 2(1+2+...+20) = 2 √ó [20(21)/2] = 420
Average = 420/20 = 21

Or use formula: Average = n+1 = 20+1 = 21

Example 3: Average of first 15 odd numbers.
Numbers: 1, 3, 5, ..., 29
Sum = n¬≤ = 15¬≤ = 225
Average = 225/15 = 15

Or use formula: Average = n = 15

Multiples Average:

Example 1: Find average of first 10 multiples of 7.
Numbers: 7, 14, 21, ..., 70
Average = (7 + 70)/2 = 77/2 = 38.5

Or: These are 7√ó1, 7√ó2, ..., 7√ó10
Average = 7 √ó (average of 1 to 10)
        = 7 √ó 5.5 = 38.5

Example 2: Average of first 8 multiples of 5.
Average = 5 √ó (1+2+...+8)/8
        = 5 √ó [8(9)/2]/8
        = 5 √ó 4.5
        = 22.5

Range Average:

Example 1: Find average of all numbers from 10 to 50.
These are consecutive: 10, 11, 12, ..., 50
Average = (10 + 50)/2 = 30

Example 2: Average of all even numbers from 20 to 80.
Numbers: 20, 22, 24, ..., 80
Average = (20 + 80)/2 = 50

Example 3: Average of all multiples of 7 between 100 and 200.
First multiple: 105 (7√ó15)
Last multiple: 196 (7√ó28)
Average = (105 + 196)/2 = 150.5

Incorrect to Correct:

Example 1: Average of 20 numbers is 50. Later found that 65 was wrongly read as 56. Find correct average.

Solution:
Wrong sum = 20 √ó 50 = 1000
Correction = 65 - 56 = +9
Correct sum = 1000 + 9 = 1009
Correct average = 1009/20 = 50.45

Example 2: Average of 15 observations is 32. If average of first 8 is 28 and of last 8 is 35, find 8th observation.

Solution:
Total sum = 15 √ó 32 = 480
Sum of first 8 = 8 √ó 28 = 224
Sum of last 8 = 8 √ó 35 = 280

If we add both: 224 + 280 = 504
This includes 8th observation twice
So, 504 - 480 = 24 (8th observation counted twice)
Therefore, 8th observation = 24

Verification:
First 7 observations sum = 224 - 24 = 200
Last 7 observations sum = 280 - 24 = 256
Total = 200 + 24 + 256 = 480 ‚úì

Overlapping Average:

Example: Average of first 10 numbers is 20, average of last 10 is 30. If average of all 18 numbers is 27, find average of middle 2 numbers (9th and 10th).

Solution:
Sum of first 10 = 10 √ó 20 = 200
Sum of last 10 = 10 √ó 30 = 300
Sum of all 18 = 18 √ó 27 = 486

Sum of first 10 + Sum of last 10 = 200 + 300 = 500
This counts middle 2 numbers twice
So, 500 - 486 = 14 (middle 2 counted twice)
Middle 2 numbers sum = 14
Average of middle 2 = 14/2 = 7

Maximum/Minimum Problems:

Example 1: Average of 5 numbers is 30. If four numbers are 25, 28, 32, 35, find the fifth.
Total = 5 √ó 30 = 150
Sum of 4 = 25 + 28 + 32 + 35 = 120
Fifth = 150 - 120 = 30

Example 2: Average of 6 numbers is 20. Largest is 35 and smallest is 12. Find average of remaining 4.
Total of 6 = 6 √ó 20 = 120
Sum of largest and smallest = 35 + 12 = 47
Sum of remaining 4 = 120 - 47 = 73
Average of 4 = 73/4 = 18.25

Ratio and Average:

Example: Ages of A, B, C are in ratio 2:3:4. If average age is 27, find their ages.

Solution:
Let ages be 2x, 3x, 4x
Average = (2x + 3x + 4x)/3 = 9x/3 = 3x
Given: 3x = 27
x = 9

Ages: A = 18, B = 27, C = 36

Percentage and Average:

Example: A number is 20% more than average of 40, 50, 60. Find the number.

Solution:
Average = (40 + 50 + 60)/3 = 150/3 = 50
Number = 50 + 20% of 50
       = 50 + 10 = 60

Two Averages:

Example: Average of x and y is 20. Average of y and z is 24. If z = 30, find x.

Solution:
(x + y)/2 = 20 ‚Üí x + y = 40 ...(1)
(y + z)/2 = 24 ‚Üí y + z = 48 ...(2)

From (2): y + 30 = 48 ‚Üí y = 18
From (1): x + 18 = 40 ‚Üí x = 22

Comparing Averages:

Example: Average of 10 numbers is 20 and average of 8 numbers is 25. Which set has greater total?

Solution:
Total of first set = 10 √ó 20 = 200
Total of second set = 8 √ó 25 = 200
Both equal!

(Average alone doesn't determine which is greater; count matters)

Exam Shortcuts:
- For consecutive: (First + Last)/2
- For n natural: (n+1)/2
- For n even numbers: n+1
- For n odd numbers: n
- For overlapping: count what's included twice
- For wrong values: add/subtract correction

Common Patterns:
- First and last group overlap at one point
- Wrong entry needs correction, not replacement
- When everyone ages equally, average ages equally
- For range a to b: average = (a+b)/2

question.questionText: The average of first 10 natural numbers is 5.5 and the average of first 10 even natural numbers is 11. What is the sum of both averages?
question.explanation: Average of first 10 natural numbers = (10+1)/2 = 5.5. Average of first 10 even numbers = 10+1 = 11. Sum = 5.5 + 11 = 16.5. Answer: 16.5.

slides.title: Shortcuts and Quick Methods
slides.content:
Learn efficient techniques to solve average problems quickly in exams.

Balancing Method:

When numbers are close to a value, use that as reference.

Example 1: Average of 47, 52, 48, 51, 45, 53

Reference: 50 (middle value)
Deviations from 50:
47 ‚Üí -3
52 ‚Üí +2
48 ‚Üí -2
51 ‚Üí +1
45 ‚Üí -5
53 ‚Üí +3

Sum of deviations = -3+2-2+1-5+3 = -4
Average deviation = -4/6 = -0.67
Average = 50 + (-0.67) = 49.33

This method is fast when numbers cluster around a value.

Grouping Method:

Combine numbers for easy calculation.

Example: Average of 23, 27, 31, 29, 25
Group in pairs:
(23 + 27) = 50
(31 + 29) = 60
25 (alone)

Sum = 50 + 60 + 25 = 135
Average = 135/5 = 27

Assumed Average:

Assume an average, find deviation, adjust.

Example: 98, 102, 101, 99, 100, 103

Assume average = 100
Deviations: -2, +2, +1, -1, 0, +3
Sum = +3
Adjustment = 3/6 = 0.5
Actual average = 100 + 0.5 = 100.5

AP Shortcut:

For arithmetic progression:
Average = (First term + Last term)/2
Or = Middle term (if odd count)

Example 1: 5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30
Average = (5 + 30)/2 = 17.5

Example 2: 3, 7, 11, 15, 19
Middle term = 11 = Average

Quick Division:

For repeated numbers:

Example: Average of 20, 20, 20, 30, 30
= (3√ó20 + 2√ó30)/5
= (60 + 60)/5
= 120/5 = 24

Increase/Decrease Impact:

1. When one number increases by k:
Average increases by k/n (where n = count)

Example: Average of 5 numbers is 20. One number increases by 10.
New average = 20 + 10/5 = 20 + 2 = 22

2. When all numbers increase by k:
Average increases by k

Example: Average of 6 numbers is 30. All increase by 5.
New average = 30 + 5 = 35

3. When all numbers are multiplied by k:
Average is multiplied by k

Example: Average of numbers is 15. All doubled.
New average = 15 √ó 2 = 30

Replacement Quick Method:

Old average = A, Count = n
Number x replaced by y
New average = A + (y-x)/n

Example: Average of 10 numbers is 50. Number 40 replaced by 70.
New average = 50 + (70-40)/10
            = 50 + 30/10
            = 50 + 3 = 53

Equal Distance Formula Shortcut:

For average speed with equal distances:
2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)

Memory trick: "2 times product over sum"

Example: Speeds 30 and 60 km/h
Average = (2√ó30√ó60)/(30+60) = 3600/90 = 40 km/h

Equal Time Formula:

For equal time: Simple average
(v‚ÇÅ + v‚ÇÇ)/2

Example: 40 km/h for 2 hours, 60 km/h for 2 hours
Average = (40+60)/2 = 50 km/h

Consecutive Multiples:

Average of first n multiples of k:
= k √ó (n+1)/2

Example: Average of first 10 multiples of 7
= 7 √ó (10+1)/2
= 7 √ó 5.5 = 38.5

Number Sense:

1. Average must be between min and max
2. If all numbers equal, average = that number
3. Larger numbers pull average up
4. If n numbers have average A, sum = nA
5. Combined average is weighted by counts

Mental Calculation Tricks:

1. For numbers ending in 5:
Group and use 5s
25 + 35 + 45 = (20+30+40) + (5+5+5) = 90 + 15 = 105

2. For numbers near 100:
Use deviations
98 + 102 + 101 = 300 + (-2+2+1) = 301

3. For fractions:
Convert to decimals mentally
1/2 = 0.5, 1/4 = 0.25, 3/4 = 0.75

Option Elimination:

1. If average must be integer, eliminate decimals
2. If average must be between a and b, eliminate others
3. If average must be close to a value, eliminate far ones

Example: Average of 23, 24, 25, 26, 27
Must be 25 (middle term)
Options with 24 or 26 can be eliminated immediately

Back Calculation:

If stuck, work backwards from options.

Example: Average of 4 numbers is what?
Options: 20, 25, 30, 35
If given some numbers, try each option.

Verification Shortcuts:

1. Quick range check: Is answer between min and max?
2. Reasonableness: Does it make sense?
3. Extremes: If all numbers same, average = that number
4. Sum check: Average √ó Count = Sum (verify)

Formula Quick Reference:

1. Average = Sum/Count
2. Sum = Average √ó Count
3. First n natural: (n+1)/2
4. First n even: n+1
5. First n odd: n
6. Consecutive: (First+Last)/2
7. Equal distance speed: 2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)
8. Equal time speed: (v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)/2

Exam Time Management:

1. Easy problems (direct average): 20-30 sec
2. Medium (combined average): 40-50 sec
3. Hard (speed, complex): 60-75 sec
4. If taking > 90 sec, skip and return

Practice Focus:

1. Mental calculation speed
2. Formula recall
3. Problem type identification
4. Shortcut application
5. Verification habit

Common Exam Traps:

1. Average of averages ‚â† Overall average (unless equal counts)
2. Average speed ‚â† Average of speeds (unless equal times)
3. Including/excluding wrong values
4. Counting errors
5. Calculation mistakes

Final Tips:
- Master basic formula first
- Practice mental math
- Use shortcuts wisely
- Always verify range
- Keep calculations organized
- Double-check counting

slides.title: Problem Solving Strategy
slides.content:
Systematic approach to solve average problems efficiently in SSC GD exam.

Step-by-Step Framework:

Step 1: Read Carefully (5-10 sec)
- What is given?
- What is asked?
- What type of problem?

Step 2: Identify Type (5 sec)
- Direct calculation?
- Combined groups?
- Speed/distance?
- Age problem?
- Missing number?
- Replacement?

Step 3: Choose Method (5 sec)
- Direct formula?
- Need to find sum first?
- Can use shortcut?
- Special formula applicable?

Step 4: Calculate (30-45 sec)
- Set up equation
- Compute systematically
- Use shortcuts if available

Step 5: Verify (5 sec)
- Is answer in valid range?
- Does it match options?
- Makes logical sense?

Problem Type Recognition:

Type 1: Direct Average
Keywords: "Find average of", "What is average"
Time: 20-30 sec
Method: Sum/Count

Type 2: Finding Sum
Keywords: "Total", "Sum", "Given average is"
Time: 15-20 sec
Method: Average √ó Count

Type 3: Combined Average
Keywords: "Two groups", "Combined", "Together"
Time: 40-50 sec
Method: (n‚ÇÅA‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇA‚ÇÇ)/(n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ)

Type 4: Average Speed
Keywords: "Speed", "Distance", "Time", "Round trip"
Time: 45-60 sec
Method: Total Distance/Total Time or special formula

Type 5: Age Average
Keywords: "Age", "Years ago", "Years hence", "Born"
Time: 50-70 sec
Method: Track age changes over time

Type 6: Replacement/Change
Keywords: "Replaced", "Excluded", "Wrong entry"
Time: 40-50 sec
Method: Find difference in sum

Type 7: Consecutive Numbers
Keywords: "Consecutive", "First n natural/even/odd"
Time: 20-30 sec
Method: (First+Last)/2 or special formula

Decision Tree:

Numbers given directly?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Calculate sum and divide
‚Üí No ‚Üì

Multiple groups to combine?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Use combined average formula
‚Üí No ‚Üì

Speed/Distance involved?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Check equal distance or equal time
‚Üí No ‚Üì

Age problem with time changes?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Track how ages change
‚Üí No ‚Üì

Replacement or wrong value?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Find difference in sums
‚Üí No ‚Üì

Consecutive numbers or special series?
‚Üí Yes ‚Üí Use (First+Last)/2 or formula

Common Patterns:

Pattern 1: Finding missing number
Sum = Average √ó Count
Missing = Sum - (Given numbers)

Pattern 2: Effect of change
New average = Old + (Change/Count)

Pattern 3: Combined groups
Total sum = Sum‚ÇÅ + Sum‚ÇÇ + ...
Average = Total sum / Total count

Pattern 4: Equal distance speed
Use harmonic mean: 2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)

Pattern 5: Age after t years
New average = Old average + t

Pattern 6: Consecutive numbers
Average = Middle term or (First+Last)/2

Word Problem Clues:

"Combined" ‚Üí Add sums, add counts
"After excluding" ‚Üí Subtract from sum and count
"Replaced" ‚Üí Subtract old, add new
"Wrong entry" ‚Üí Find correction needed
"Years ago/hence" ‚Üí Adjust all ages equally
"Round trip" ‚Üí Equal distances, use special formula
"Equal time" ‚Üí Simple average of speeds
"First n natural/even/odd" ‚Üí Use special formulas

Calculation Organization:

Write clearly:
1. Given information
2. Formula/method
3. Substitution
4. Calculation
5. Final answer

Example format:
Given: Average = 30, Count = 5, Four numbers = 25,28,32,35
Find: Fifth number
Sum = 30 √ó 5 = 150
Given sum = 120
Fifth = 150 - 120 = 30

Time Management:

Easy Problems (30 sec target):
- Direct average
- Find sum from average
- Consecutive numbers
- First n natural/even/odd

Medium Problems (45 sec target):
- Combined average (2 groups)
- Simple replacement
- Missing one number
- Basic age problems

Hard Problems (60-70 sec target):
- Average speed (complex)
- Multiple replacements
- Complex age problems
- Combined average (3+ groups)
- Overlapping averages

If Stuck (>75 seconds):
1. Try working backwards from options
2. Estimate and eliminate
3. Make educated guess
4. Mark and move on

Error Prevention:

‚úó Don't add averages directly
‚úó Don't forget to count correctly
‚úó Don't use wrong formula
‚úó Don't skip verification

‚úì Always use Sum/Count method when unsure
‚úì Write down what you know
‚úì Use appropriate formula
‚úì Verify answer makes sense

Verification Checklist:

1. Range Check:
‚ñ° Is average between minimum and maximum values?

2. Calculation Check:
‚ñ° Did I count correctly?
‚ñ° Did I add/subtract correctly?
‚ñ° Did I divide by right number?

3. Logic Check:
‚ñ° Does answer make practical sense?
‚ñ° Is it close to my estimation?

4. Option Check:
‚ñ° Does answer match an option?
‚ñ° If not, where did I err?

Common Mistakes:

1. Counting errors
- Missing one number
- Counting same number twice
- Wrong total count

2. Formula confusion
- Using arithmetic mean for average speed
- Adding averages instead of sums
- Wrong combined average formula

3. Calculation errors
- Addition mistakes
- Division errors
- Decimal point errors

4. Conceptual errors
- Not accounting for time changes in age
- Forgetting to include/exclude items
- Wrong interpretation of question

Option Elimination:

1. Out of Range:
If numbers are 20, 25, 30, 35
Average must be between 20 and 35
Eliminate 15 or 40

2. Obviously Wrong:
If all numbers around 50
Average can't be 100 or 10

3. Close Estimation:
Quick mental estimate
Eliminate far options

4. Parity Check:
If sum must be even/odd
Check if average √ó count gives right parity

Practice Strategy:

2 Weeks Before Exam:
Daily:
- 20 average problems
- Mix all types
- Time each problem
- Review mistakes

1 Week Before:
Daily:
- 15 problems
- Focus on weak types
- Speed practice
- Formula revision

Day Before:
- 5 easy problems
- Formula review
- Mental math practice
- Confidence building

Exam Day Approach:

1. Scan average questions first
2. Do easy ones immediately (30 sec each)
3. Mark medium ones for second pass
4. Skip very hard ones initially
5. Return to skipped ones if time permits
6. Make educated guesses if needed

Success Mantra:

‚úì Average = Sum/Count (remember this always)
‚úì Practice builds speed
‚úì Shortcuts save time
‚úì Verification prevents errors
‚úì Stay calm and systematic
‚úì Manage time wisely
‚úì Every mark counts

slides.title: Exam Strategy and Quick Reference
slides.content:
Final preparation guide for average problems in SSC GD Elementary Mathematics.

Question Distribution:

- Averages: 2-3 questions in exam
- Time per question: 30-60 seconds
- Difficulty: Easy to Medium mostly
- Scoring potential: Very High
- Expected accuracy: 85-90%

Quick Reference Formulas:

Basic:
1. Average = Sum/Count
2. Sum = Average √ó Count
3. Count = Sum/Average

Special Series:
4. First n natural: (n+1)/2
5. First n even: n+1
6. First n odd: n
7. Consecutive: (First+Last)/2
8. Multiples of k: k(n+1)/2

Combined Average:
9. Two groups: (n‚ÇÅA‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇA‚ÇÇ)/(n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ)
10. Three groups: (n‚ÇÅA‚ÇÅ + n‚ÇÇA‚ÇÇ + n‚ÇÉA‚ÇÉ)/(n‚ÇÅ+n‚ÇÇ+n‚ÇÉ)

Average Speed:
11. General: Total Distance/Total Time
12. Equal distance: 2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)
13. Equal time: (v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)/2

Age Problems:
14. After t years: Average increases by t
15. Before t years: Average decreases by t

Change Effects:
16. One number increases by k: Average increases by k/n
17. All increase by k: Average increases by k
18. All multiplied by k: Average multiplied by k
19. Replacement: New avg = Old avg + (New-Old)/n

Must Remember:

‚úì Average lies between minimum and maximum
‚úì Can't add averages directly (need sums)
‚úì For speed: Total Distance/Total Time
‚úì Equal distance ‚â† Equal time formulas
‚úì Age increase affects all equally
‚úì Count carefully (easy to miss)
‚úì Verify answer is in range

Common Question Types:

1. Direct Calculation (30%)
"Find average of 12, 15, 18, 21, 24"
Method: Sum/Count
Time: 20-30 sec
Difficulty: Easy

2. Finding Sum/Missing Number (25%)
"Average of 5 numbers is 30, four are given"
Method: Sum = Avg √ó Count, then subtract
Time: 30-40 sec
Difficulty: Easy

3. Combined Average (20%)
"Average of 20 is 30, of 30 is 40, find combined"
Method: Add sums, divide by total count
Time: 40-50 sec
Difficulty: Medium

4. Average Speed (15%)
"Goes at 40 km/h, returns at 60 km/h"
Method: 2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ) for equal distance
Time: 45-60 sec
Difficulty: Medium

5. Age Problems (5%)
"Average age now 30, after 5 years?"
Method: Add years to average
Time: 30-40 sec
Difficulty: Easy-Medium

6. Special Series (5%)
"Average of first 20 natural numbers"
Method: (n+1)/2 formula
Time: 15-20 sec
Difficulty: Easy

Exam Day Strategy:

1. Attempt Order:
Easy (direct, special series) ‚Üí Medium (combined, missing) ‚Üí Hard (speed, complex)

2. Time Allocation:
- 30 sec for direct average
- 40 sec for combined/missing
- 50 sec for average speed
- 60 sec for complex problems
- Skip if > 75 sec, return later

3. Calculation Tips:
- Write formula first
- Calculate sum carefully
- Count numbers correctly
- Use shortcuts for speed
- Verify range

4. Must Do:
- Identify problem type immediately
- Choose appropriate formula
- Calculate systematically
- Verify answer makes sense
- Check if matches options

Error Prevention:

‚úó Don't average the averages
‚úó Don't forget speed formula (equal distance)
‚úó Don't miscount numbers
‚úó Don't skip verification
‚úó Don't confuse formulas

‚úì Use Sum/Count when unsure
‚úì For speed: Total Dist/Total Time
‚úì Count carefully
‚úì Always verify range
‚úì Use appropriate formula

Shortcuts to Remember:

1. Consecutive numbers: (First+Last)/2
2. All same numbers: Average = that number
3. AP series: Take middle term (odd count)
4. Balancing method: For numbers close together
5. n natural numbers: (n+1)/2
6. n even numbers: n+1
7. n odd numbers: n
8. Equal distance speed: 2v‚ÇÅv‚ÇÇ/(v‚ÇÅ+v‚ÇÇ)

Mental Math Practice:

Before exam, practice:
- Quick addition (5 numbers in 10 sec)
- Division by 2, 3, 4, 5 mentally
- Fractions to decimals (1/4 = 0.25)
- Speed formula (2√ó30√ó60/90 = ?)

Last Minute Revision:

Day Before Exam:
‚úì Review all formulas
‚úì Practice 5 easy problems
‚úì Revise speed formulas (most confusing)
‚úì Check special series formulas
‚úì Mental math practice

1 Hour Before:
‚úì Quick formula glance
‚úì Relax and breathe
‚úì Confidence building
‚úì Stay positive

During Exam:
‚úì Read question carefully
‚úì Identify type
‚úì Choose method
‚úì Calculate systematically
‚úì Verify answer
‚úì Move on if stuck
‚úì Return to skipped ones
‚úì Manage time well

Expected Performance:

With Good Practice:
- Easy questions: 95%+ accuracy
- Medium questions: 85%+ accuracy
- Hard questions: 70%+ accuracy
- Overall: 85-90% achievable
- Time: Average 40-45 sec/question

Scoring Strategy:

1. Averages is high-scoring topic
2. Formulas are straightforward
3. Calculations are simple
4. Practice improves speed significantly
5. Accuracy is very achievable
6. Don't leave any average question unattempted

Topic Interconnections:

Averages connects with:
- Ratio (weighted averages)
- Percentage (percentage changes)
- Speed-Distance-Time (average speed)
- Age problems (ratio and proportions)

Understanding these connections helps solve complex problems.

Success Checklist:

‚ñ° Formulas memorized
‚ñ° Practiced 100+ problems
‚ñ° Speed improved (under 45 sec average)
‚ñ° Shortcuts learned
‚ñ° Special formulas remembered
‚ñ° Average speed formula clear
‚ñ° Combined average method mastered
‚ñ° Verification habit developed
‚ñ° Time management planned
‚ñ° Confident and prepared

Final Confidence Boost:

- Averages is logical and learnable
- Limited formulas to remember
- Practice makes you faster
- Shortcuts are very helpful
- You've practiced well
- Trust your preparation
- Stay systematic
- You can score full marks!

Remember: Average = Sum/Count
This one formula solves 80% of problems!

Good luck! You've got this! üéØ
